qas.question: Which articles allow the soverign to refise consent even when the bills have been passed through the Legislative assembly?
What statement by King George Tupou emphasized democracy?

answers.text: he would be guided by his prime minister in the exercising of his powers

qas.question: In which year was the Arms and Ammunitions (Amemndment) Bill adopted?
In what month did the King veto the Arms and Ammunitions Amendment Bill?
What articles empower the sovereign to grant royal assent?
The kingdom moved away from democracy in what year?
An Art and Ammunitions Bill was adopted in what year?
What bill was adopted by eight votes to ten?
How many member of the assembly were charge with legal possession of firearms?

context: Articles <a0_0><b4_0>41 and 68<b4_0/><a0_0/> of the constitution empower the sovereign to withhold royal assent from bills adopted by the Legislative Assembly. In <b5_0>2010<b5_0/>, the kingdom moved towards greater democracy, with King George Tupou V saying that <a1_0>he would be guided by his prime minister in the exercising of his powers<a1_0/>. Nonetheless, this does not preclude an independent royal decision to exercise a right of veto. In November <a2_0><b6_0>2011<b6_0/><a2_0/>, the assembly adopted an <b7_0>Arms and Ammunitions (Amendment) Bill<b7_0/>, which reduced the possible criminal sentences for the illicit possession of firearms. The bill was adopted by ten votes to eight. <b8_0>Two<b8_0/> members of the assembly had recently been charged with the illicit possession of firearms. The Prime Minister, Lord Tuʻivakanō, voted in favour of the amendment. Members of the opposition denounced the bill and asked the King to veto it, which he did in <a3_0>December<a3_0/>.
